abstract.p: Keratin sponge/hydrogels, described in Part I as the products of oxidation and reduction hydrolysis of fine and coarse wool fibers, were examined as excipient-platforms for the delivery of riboflavin. By absorption through well-defined pores and networks, saturated moisture equilibrium was reached within one hour with swelling ratios of 3.7–5.7. Riboflavin uptake by the four different keratin sponge/hydrogels was from 27.9 to 224 µg. Within 60 minutes, reductive keratin sponge/hydrogels from fine and coarse wool, and the oxidative species from fine wool, released 100% riboflavin at 1.58–1.73% per minute and oxidative sponge/hydrogel from coarse wool released 48% riboflavin at 0.8% riboflavin per minute. Rates of riboflavin release were faster within the initial 10 minutes where reductive sponge/hydrogels released 80–84% riboflavin at 8.0–8.4% per minute and oxidative sponge/hydrogels released 26–63% riboflavin at 2.6–6.3% per minute. Riboflavin delivery at timed intervals was examined with the Korsmeyer–Peppas mathematical model for fractional release. Release patterns followed quasi-Fickian diffusion of the drug by transport through channels and voids. All keratin sponge/hydrogels functioned as site-specific agents with two-stage delivery where immediate release of riboflavin was followed by a period of prolonged, lower dosage release. Swelling studies, the mobility of water, and the behavior of riboflavin release favorably framed keratin sponge/hydrogels as microfluidic devices with implied applications for advanced biomedical and biotechnological applications.

body.p: Hydrogel biopolymers – insoluble, three-dimensional, and hydrophilic – are capable of absorbing and releasing large amounts of fluids while maintaining structural integrity through internal physical and molecular associations, crosslinking, and crystallite entanglements. Applications include contact lenses, biosensor membranes, artificial heart liners, artificial skin material, cell cultivation, and drug delivery devices.1 Sponge/hydrogels of keratin protein provide super-molecular, dense aggregates in a porous matrix. These materials functioned as biocompatible orthopedic supports to restore form and function.2 Implanted keratin was biocompatible and useful for cell tissue and scaffolds for fibroblasts as anti-thrombogenic biomaterial.3–5 Keratin gels, mats, scaffolds, and films are of significant interest for biotechnological and biomedical applications.6–14 Keratin functional platforms adhere naturally to keratinous substrates, such as hair, skin, and nails, and can deliver beneficial agents for health, medicine, and personal care. As a solid matrix, keratin sponge/hydrogel can be examined for implantation where silicone-derived materials are typically used.14–23

In Part I keratin protein was isolated from the hydrolysis of wool fiber and formed into sponge/hydrogels. These materials were examined as ionic platforms with properties characteristically requisite for agent-uptake and delivery. Porosity and differences in topologies were documented in scanning electron micrographs. These materials exhibited thermal and mechanical stability, shown by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and rheology measurements. Viscoelastic behavior, measured by storage modulus G′, and loss modulus, G″, characterized them as strong gels. In Part II we examined keratin sponge/hydrogel as excipient material by documenting uptake and release of moisture, uptake of riboflavin, and release of riboflavin according to kinetic diffusion models. We applied diffusional solute release mechanisms to analyze the functional release of riboflavin solubilized in simulated gastric fluid (SGF). Riboflavin (CAS number 83-88-5), vitamin B2, a yellow, hydrophilic, tricyclic molecule, is an easily absorbed micronutrient essential to health in humans and animals for activating vitamin B6, vitamin B9 (folate), vitamin B3 (niacin), and vitamin K. It is essential for healing and recovery from burns, wounds, surgery, and other injuries and is essential for proper immune system functioning, and reinforcing the body’s natural antibody reserves. The US recommended daily allowance (RDA) for most adults is 2.4 micrograms (http://www.nal.usda.gov/fnic/DRI/DRI_Thiamin/87-122_150.pdf). The benefits of treating keratin substrates with riboflavin are well documented.24–26

Riboflavin is soluble in SGF (pH 1.2) and slightly soluble in water (0.01 g/100 mL at 25℃). The isoalloxazine ring of riboflavin at the N-10 position contains a ribityl carbohydrate chain connected to four hydroxyl groups. As a neutral molecule, riboflavin at low pH can behave as a polyprotic acid or base. In SGF, pH 1.2, riboflavin’s basic character promotes reactivity with keratin through electrostatic interaction. It was assumed that the binding between riboflavin and keratin was non-covalent.27,28 Others have reported riboflavin loading and release from hydrogel polymer networks. In vitro release studies of riboflavin in SGF were reported with release profiles of riboflavin entrapped in calcium alginate and polyglycidyl methacrylate sodium alginate-grafted hydrogels.29 Patel and Amiji30 investigated the release of riboflavin in SGF from chitosan-polyethylene oxide (PEO) hydrogel for in vitro site-specific delivery to the stomach and reported the swelling ratio (weight of the swollen hydrogel/weight of the dry hydrogel) and release kinetics by applying the Korsmeyer–Peppas model, Mt/M∞ = k.tn.

sec.title: Morphology features
sec.p:
In Part I we isolated ARS DD and M1-1 keratin sponge/hydrogels with the intact chemical and microstructure of native keratin. ARS DD appeared mat-like and fibrous and M1-1 appeared smooth and homogeneous. We found that keratin sponge/hydrogels formed by oxidation hydrolysis (ARS DD) and reduction hydrolysis (M1-1) were amphoteric, swelling-controlled systems capable of dynamic absorption and desorption. Figure 1 shows a crenulated structure and associated microfibers with channels of discrete, interconnected, porous walls and voids. Figure 1.
Keratin sponge/hydrogels: ARS DD (a)–(e) where (a)–(c) are hydrated, (d) is dehydrated, and (e) is lyophilized powder; M1-1 (f)–(j) where (f)–(h) are hydrated, (i) is dehydrated, and (j) is lyophilized powder.

sec.title: Response to moisture
sec.p: In four independent experiments, fully hydrated keratin sponge/hydrogels in triplicate, 300–500 mg each, were vacuum-oven dried to the bone-dry state in 12 mL Pyrex® standard weighing bottles (Corning, external 24/12 taper joint). At timed intervals throughout drying, constant dry weights to within +/− 10 mg were recorded. Moisture release was determined from sample weights of fully hydrated samples (Ws), and weights at prescribed times of hydration (Wt) from Moisture release, %=(Ws-Wt)/Ws×100

The dried samples were placed in a closed system above a saturated K2CrO4 salt solution for swelling until moisture equilibrium was reached.31 The Swelling ratio, Q,30,32 was calculated using sample dry weight, Wd, and the weight of the swollen sample, Ws, in the equation Q=Ws/Wd

sec.title: Absorption of simulated gastric fluid
sec.p: Oven-dried replicate samples, each of fine and coarse keratin sponge/hydrogels, ARS DD and M1-1, were exposed to SGF, pH 1.2, supplied as 0.2% w/w NaCl in 0.7% v/v HCl (Ricca Chemical Company, Texas). Each sample was placed into individual 15 mL perforated, conical BD Falcon® tubes to which were added 12 mL SGF. The samples were agitated in a 37℃ shaker bath. At 10 minute intervals, the samples were withdrawn and centrifuged for 10 minutes on a fixed-speed Cole-Palmer Centrifuge at 3400 rpm to remove unabsorbed SGF. Uptake of SGF was measured from swelling ratio, Q.

sec.title: Absorption of riboflavin
sec.p: A 6.5 ppm riboflavin stock solution (1.14 mg (-)-riboflavin powder, C7H2ON4O6, Sigma-Aldrich Company, St. Louis, MO, 376.36 g/mole) was prepared in 215 ml SGF. Aliquot concentrations of the stock solution, 0–6.5 ppm, were used to generate a standard curve for riboflavin absorbance detection at 265 nm. The oven-dried, keratin sponge/hydrogel replicates of fine and coarse ARS DD and M1-1 were submersed in the riboflavin solution and placed into an Orbit Environ Shaker from Lab-Line Instruments, Inc. (Melrose Park, IL) for shaking at 37℃ until equilibrium saturation was reached. The riboflavin-impregnated samples were vacuum-dried at 50℃. Then the dry riboflavin-impregnated samples were individually exposed to 50 ml SGF with a volume of 1 ml for every 0.5 mg of sample at 37℃ with shaking. Aliquots of each sample solution were taken every 2 minutes for the first 30 minutes, and then every 5 minutes for the first hour from which 1 ml aliquots were removed for ultraviolet (UV) detection of riboflavin. The aliquots were each transferred to a QS 283 quartz cuvette from Hellma Analytics and analyzed using a Cary 50 Conc UV-Visible Spectrophotometer from Varian Instruments (Walnut Creek, CA). The amount of riboflavin, mg, in SGF was found from the slope equation of the standard curve for absorbance versus riboflavin concentration. The uptake of riboflavin at timed intervals was determined as the swelling ratio, Q.33

sec.title: Mathematical release models
sec.p: In order to clarify the interaction of water within the hydrophilic keratin sponge/hydrogels, mathematical models for controlled release were applied as zero-order, first-order, Hixson–Crowell, Higuchi, and Korsmeyer–Peppas expressions. We treated the riboflavin release data accordingly as cumulative percentage drug release versus time (zero-order kinetic model); log cumulative of percentage drug remaining versus time (first-order kinetic model); cube root of drug percentage remaining in matrix versus time (Hixson–Crowell cube root law); cumulative percentage drug release versus square root of time (Higuchi model); and log cumulative percentage drug release versus log time (Korsmeyer–Peppas model).34–41 Zero-order rate equations assumed the rate of drug release was independent of its concentration in the equation, C = ko t, where ko is a zero-order rate constant expressed in units of concentration/ time, t. The first-order rate equation described the release from a system where release rate was concentration dependent: Log C = Log Co − k t / 2.303, where Co is the initial concentration of the drug and k is first-order constant. The Hixson–Crowell model described the release from systems where there was a change in surface area: Qo1/3 − Qt1/3 = kHC, where Qt was the amount of drug released in time to, Qo was the initial amount of the drug, and kHC was the rate constant. Higuchi described drug release from a solid substance by assuming that diffusion of the dissolved drug through the matrix was the rate-controlling stage in the overall release process. Accordingly, the square root of a time-dependent process was based on the Fickian diffusion process in the equation Q = kt1/2, where k was the constant reflecting the design variables of the system, utilizing the equation, Mt / M∞ = kt1/2, and Mt was the cumulative weight-amount of drug at time t. The term, k, was the Higuchi release constant determined by plotting the cumulative percent of drug release against the square root of time in hours to find the slope of the corresponding line. The Korsmeyer–Peppas model, Mt / M∞ = k.tn, Mt / M∞ represented fractional drug release at time t, with k the rate release constant and n the slope (release exponent) characterizing the transport mechanism dependent on the geometry of the device. The Korsmeyer–Peppas drug release rate constant (k, %/h) was calculated as the slope of linear regression lines fitted to the log Mt / M∞, where M∞ was the total amount of drug absorbed or released at equilibrium (after an infinite time, t).36 To characterize diffusional behavior, tortuosity, and porosity of the sponge/hydrogels, which influence drug release, we found n from the log–log plots, as a determinant of Fickian diffusion. Values of n < 0.5 indicated quasi-Fickian diffusion.

sec.title: Moisture absorption and release
sec.p:
All keratin sponge/hydrogels released 50% moisture within 70 minutes, as shown in Figure 2(a). Differences in pore size, type, tortuosity, and surface roughness did not secure the entrapment of water at the conditions applied for drying. Figure 2.
Dynamic moisture release (a) and absorption (b).

When the dried samples were rehydrated, as shown in Figure 2(b), moisture equilibrium was achieved within 241–562 hours with 41–47% absorption for M1-1 samples. ARS DD samples achieved 62–74% moisture equilibrium within the same time period, following the same kinetic profiles for moisture absorption. With moisture absorption and release predictably the same for all keratin sponge/hydrogels, selection of a particular type would be based upon the moisture content and the ability for a host to accommodate the size of the swollen material that can be regulated, based on the extent of exposure to moisture, as shown in Table 1. sec.title: Swelling in simulated gastric fluid
sec.p:
Swelling in SGF was appreciably greater than swelling in moisture from a saturated environment. By placing keratin sponge/hydrogels in an acidic environment in SGF, it was expected that the sorption of SGF (pH 1.2) would follow wool dyeing in acidic medium where wool is protonated for attraction of anionic dye. Equilibrium saturation was reached with higher swelling ratios, as shown in Figure 3 and Table 2, indicating the pH-sensitivity of the materials. Kinetic profiles were similar, reaching equilibrium saturation within 55 minutes. M1-1 fine with more compact structure swelled less, reaching equilibrium saturation within 60 minutes. Figure 3.

sec.title: Diffusional release of riboflavin
sec.p:
Kinetic swelling in Figure 4 was rapid up to 20 minutes. Maximum swelling for M1-1 coarse was achieved within 3 minutes. Within 20 minutes, swelling followed the order: M1-1 coarse >ARS DD coarse = ARS DD fine >M1-1 fine. Note that equilibrium swelling was achieved within 20 minutes in riboflavin/SGF compared to 55 minutes for swelling in SGF. We attributed the difference in kinetic behavior to electrostatic interaction of riboflavin and keratin at pH 1.2. Figure 4.
Riboflavin absorption by keratin sponge/hydrogels.

Table 6 was constructed to elucidate diffusion by comparing relevant parameters describing the best fit of the data acquired by applying the various mechanistic models. In Table 6 for the Korsmeyer–Peppas model, a value of n = <0.5, indicated that the time-release of riboflavin through the sponge/hydrogel followed a quasi-Fickian diffusion mechanism. When determining n, it was necessary to use only the initial part of the release curve where Mt / M∞ < 0.6. When analyzing data of drug release from porous systems, the n value would most likely be less than 0.5 due to a combination of mechanisms based on diffusion through a swollen matrix and through with water-filled pores that would shift the release exponent toward smaller values.34,36–41 From Table 6, the Korsmeyer–Peppas model was clearly the best match with greater than 95% correlation for every sample across all time intervals. We assumed that n < 0.5 values could be explained as a result of the combined mechanisms (diffusion partially through a swollen matrix and partially through water-filled pores).38 The Hixson–Crowell model was slightly less strongly correlated than the Higuchi model, indicating that riboflavin transport was facilitated by a diffusion mechanism as opposed to dissolution. The fact that the zero-order release model was a little more strongly correlated than the first-order release model indicated that the drug release rate was independent of the concentration of dissolved substance. Riboflavin release was best described for both M1-1 fine and ARS DD fine by an unspecified diffusion mechanism, and for M1-1 coarse and ARS DD coarse, as a quasi-pore-size-dependent Fickian diffusion mechanism. Based on these observations, the keratin sponge/hydrogels can be considered for controlled release when an initial immediate-release dose followed by an extended-release dose is prescribed. Keratin sponge/hydrogels exhibited dual-release in delivering higher dosages immediately and lower dosages over prolonged time.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In Part II, investigations showed the potential of keratin sponge/hydrogel to function as renewable biomaterial for in vitro delivery of the model drug, riboflavin. Uniquely amphoteric and highly functionalized keratin is positioned favorably when compared to other natural and synthetic sponge/hydrogels used as drug delivery systems. These keratin materials proved capable of swelling and drug release in the low pH environment of stomach fluid. They exhibited dual-control kinetics for riboflavin release. Formed in Part I from oxidation and reduction of wool fibers, they demonstrated high elasticity with reversible deformation, and the ability to entrap and release moisture under stress while maintaining their structural integrity. Typical hydrogel behavior was demonstrated in Part II by sorption studies showing that from equilibrium saturation, these materials released up to 83–93% moisture at comparable rates within 350 hours. All sponge/hydrogels proved responsive to pH change, evidenced by greater swelling in SGF. From SGF, fine and coarse oxidative and reductive species released 100% riboflavin (29–91 µg) within 60 minutes, except for coarse oxidative sponge/hydrogel, which released 31 µg riboflavin with fractional release, 48%. Within 10 minutes, rates of release followed the order: M1-1 fine >M1-1 coarse >ARS DD fine >ARS DD, releasing respectively from 84% to 26% riboflavin. Implications can be drawn for controlled, timed, sustained release. Applied kinetic mathematical models showed that Fickian diffusion control for riboflavin release was most effective in ARS DD sponge/hydrogels with highest diffusional exponents, n, according to Korsmeyer–Peppas. Highest rates of release of riboflavin, k, exhibited by fine sponge/hydrogels indicated highest interaction between the drug and porous matrix. The release data of unbound moisture and riboflavin from the keratin sponge/hydrogels, fit to release curves, proved that the hydrogels served as diffusion barriers to release riboflavin mainly by Fickian diffusion-control, whereby water diffusion into the hydrogel occurred much faster than the relaxation of the polymer chains. We have shown that swelling kinetics occurred according to the diffusion control as a mechanism for release and that sponge/hydrogels acted as diffusion barriers to make them useful for slow release with retention of riboflavin.39 Conclusions from this study should invite in vitro and in vivo studies as needed to explore possibilities for synergistic medical treatments utilizing keratin sponge/hydrogels.
